title: Effect of light on RNA degradation

content.description:
Researchers investigated whether time of day affects the rate at which certain <math alttext="m R N A’s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by plants are broken down. At either <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hour after the start of the light period (morning) or <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours after the start of the light period (afternoon), the researchers treated identical plant seedlings with a compound that blocks transcription (<math alttext="time equals 0 minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>ime</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>⁢</mo><mtext>min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The researchers measured the percent remaining of two <math alttext="m R N A’s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>mRNA H</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, over the course of <math alttext="120" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes. The data are shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Degradation of <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> over time after exposure to light for <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hour (morning) or <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours (afternoon)
content.question: Based on the data, which of the following best describes the relationship between light and the degradation of <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>mRNA G</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: Exposure to light causes the degradation of both <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> degrade at the same rate during morning exposure to light.

A longer exposure to light increases the rate of <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> degradation but not of <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> degradation.

Exposure to more-intense afternoon light causes both <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to degrade more rapidly in the afternoon than in the morning.

content.answer: A longer exposure to light increases the rate of <math alttext="m R N A G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> degradation but not of <math alttext="m R N A H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> degradation.
